The diagnosis of Graves' disease is based on the measurement of TSH receptor antibodies. A high titre confirms the diagnosis (specific biological signs).

The non-specific biological signs are :

- lower cholesterol and triglyceride levels (depending on previous figures)

- discreet [[Hyperglycaemia SD-208|hyperglycaemia]] (sometimes) and, above all, aggravation of associated diabetes.

- elevated liver enzymes

- leukoneutropenia with relative lymphocytosis

question.title: What is a non-specific biological sign of Graves' disease?
question.description: A high titre of TSH receptor antibodies confirms the diagnosis of Graves' disease. What is another non-specific biological sign of the disease?

option_a.title: Elevated liver enzymes
option_a.description: A common laboratory finding in patients with Graves' disease

option_b.title: Leukocytosis with relative neutrophilia
option_b.description: An increase in white blood cells with a relative increase in neutrophils

option_c.title: Hypertriglyceridemia
option_c.description: An increase in triglyceride levels in the blood

option_d.title: Leukopenia with relative lymphocytosis
option_d.description: A decrease in white blood cells with a relative increase in lymphocytes

correct_option.title: E
correct_option.description: The letter of the correct option
